title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Mexican peso on 29 November 2019?
possible_answers: More than Mex$18.5000 but less than Mex$19.5000
preds:
What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Mexican peso on 29 November 2019?
I should have gone 50-50 at the start, the break point is too hard to call.

Tested 19.500 a week ago and fell back
Testing 19.500 once again (19.47).
Likely will fall back - but such short-term moves are basically random - so the best I can give is is 2:1 odds.

What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Mexican peso on 29 November 2019?
The peso appears to be slipping as we near year end and firms tidy accounts.
19.5 still provides major resistance. May hold for at least another week.
Hattip to @Joseph-Noko for his excellent analysis on the why as well as the how. Bloomberg says 19.4066 on Nov 21, still providing headroom for the likely bucket.

The sharp depreciation in the value of the Peso against the USD is part of a broader, secular appreciation of the USD against Latin American currencies.  Last week, the Banco de México (Banxico) slashed its overnight interbank interest rate by 25 basis points to 7.50%. This was the third time this year that Banxico had reduced borrowing costs. For a time, the Mexican peso rallied, perhaps with speculators looking to take advantage of the Peso's seeming carry-trade appeal, but with deteriorating macro-fundamentals, including the risk of downgrades of Pemex and Mexican sovereign debt, the USD is likely to continue to test and eventually break 19.5.  At present, the USD-MXN rate is 19.4568. 19.01549-19.1041 seems to be the present support zone for the rate and Friday saw the USD-MXN close at its highest level in a month. USD-MXN seems to be testing 19.4048-19.4904. Today's daily range so far has been 19.3398-19.4912.  Without having broken 19.5, I think the odds of this happening have risen, but in terms of our timeline, it may be that the USD-MXN is still within 18.5-19.5 by close of challenge, so I am only modestly altering my forecast until 19.5 has been successively broken and support achieved at that rate.
Looking back several weeks, prices have tended to be lowest on Fridays. Current rate is $19.39 but it has not been above $19.50 in a while. With the challenge closing soon, I'm going all in.

Outside view:
•	Base rate (1Y)
o	Less than $17.5000: 0%
o	Between $17.5000 and $18.5000 inclusive: 0%
o	More than $18.5000 but less than $19.5000: 74%
o	Between $19.5000 and $20.5000 inclusive: 25%
o	More than $20.5000: 1%
•	Current: 19.2875 Inside view:
•	What influences FX rates
o	Differences in inflation
	High inflation= weaker currency
o	Differences in interest rates
	Cutting interest rates implies weaker economy weaker currency
o	Current account deficits
o	Public debt
o	Terms of trade
o	Strong economic performance •	What would need to happen in each for that scenario to become a reality
o	Less than $17.5000: extreme depreciation of USD, extreme appreciation of MXN
o	Between $17.5000 and $18.5000 inclusive: modest depreciation of USD, modest appreciation of MXN
o	More than $18.5000 but less than $19.5000: stay the same, minimal depreciation of USD, minimal appreciation of MXN
o	Between $19.5000 and $20.5000 inclusive: modest appreciation of USD, modest depreciation of MXN
o	More than $20.5000: Extreme appreciation of USD, extreme depreciation of MXN •	General note: MXN cited as being closely tied to developments in US/global sentiments overall
o	Considering outlook is fairly neutral to disappointing I would keep USD/MXN in the $18.5000-$19.5000 bucket (+1%) •	More than $18.5000 but less than $19.5000:
o	Minimal movement
	In the past, Banxico rate cut resulted in short term spike and return to previous FX rate
	Even with recent high of over $19.3300, $19.5000 considered a barrier/resistance point making it hard to cross (+1%)
o	Move the same direction
o	Minimal depreciation of USD
	Trade talks fall through (or Trump tweets imply that) •	Between $19.5000 and $20.5000 inclusive:
o	Appreciation of USD
	Release of data that suggests strong economy
	Advances in trade war with China (+1%)
	Trade deal with European automakers (+2-3%)
o	Depreciation of MXN
	Interest rate cuts- spike lasts on average 1.5 weeks (+2%)
•	During last cut, two members (of five) wanted more aggressive cuts
•	Will there be a cut?
o	Probably (only one source has said no)
	Rise in inflation
•	Inflation has remained below expectation, so a rise would be seen as a good thing •	FX futures
o	Futures put the range in the $18.5000 to $19.5000 bucket

Presently testing near-term resistance of 19.356, with the trend lines in a downward direction since Sept.
Yearly range has been 18.7 to 20.6 - with tariffs on MX goods being the prime driver  - there's been no talk of that for a while, so MXN seems to be strengthening from September onward.
Nevertheless - with a delta of only 139 between present MXN 19361 and MXN 19500  - that's less than a 1% move with 9 trading days left. Randomness alone could push it/keep it above 19500 on Nov 29.
Futures pricing for Dec delivery is 19391.
So I still give it 3:2 that it won't be across the 19500 barrier on Nov 30 - but recent price action/direction has to be taken into account as a contrary-wise assessment.
It looks despite that news about the USMCA and US-China trade deal is uncertain, the appetite for riskier emerging markets is not waning.

For the most part my forecasts are based on the 5 year historical base rate. From there, I also checked in and adjusted based on highs/lows over the last five years, one year, and year-to-date. I looked into a few analysts who predicted the currency exchange rate would be within the 18.5-19.5 range, although I did not see or have time to look into their models of why they think so, nor did I see any of the assumptions they are making in those predictions.  I also read about other factors that could influence currency rates in general (i.e. Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Balance of Payments, Government Debt, Terms of Trade, Political Stability & Performance, Recession, and Speculation), and started to do some research on interest rate announcements and their impact on the rate. There is a Mexican interest rate announcement on November 15th that may impact the price, but I didn’t incorporate this into my estimates because I didn’t have enough time to do more thorough analysis on this how this might impact the price since there is still 15 days until the question closes - that’s something I could work on in the future. I also would like to look more into the “Political Stability” and “Terms of Trades” factors that impact currency rates and read more about the political climate and trade negotiations between the U.S. and Mexico since MarketSource pieces I read often cite that currencies move on this news.
What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Mexican peso on 29 November 2019? Near term strengthening of the peso
Peso continues to appreciate. Just two weeks to go.

Banxico cut rates by expected 25 bp and, I believe,  the move to depreciate peso thus weakened though more cuts are expected. Increasing probability that peso stays in the current bucket due to limited timeframe of the question
What will be the end-of-day closing value for the U.S. dollar against the Mexican peso on 29 November 2019?

Using data from the Banco de México's Sistema de Información Económica (https://www.banxico.org.mx/SieInternet/consultarDirectorioInternetAction.do?sector=6&accion=consultarDirectorioCuadros&locale=en), I realized a comprehensive base rate, going back all the way to 1954, would wildly overstate the base rate for "Less than 17.5", given that the 52-week range is 18.7480-20.6572 and the peso has seen a sharp depreciation against the dollar over the last 4-5 years, so I started off on 12/08/1954 and my base rates were established as: Less than 17.5: 4.3%
17.5-18.5: 20.1%
18.5-19.5%: 52.9%
19.5-20.5: 16.8%
20.5% plus: 5.9%. At this stage, I think I can confidently rule out anything below 18.5 and proportionally increase my bet on a 18.5-19.5 range.
Update to reflect the passage of time
Peso is depreciating and dangerously close to the lower bin. Adjusting accordingly...

December futures indicates 19308 and November futures 19245 (if I'm reading those charts right).
Recent monthly historicals also reflect range-bound activity, with MXN strengthening from where it started October at around 19626.
To me - constrained strengthening throughout November, sudden tweet-storm notwithstanding.

Next Feds meeting is after the question closing date and the overwhelming expectation is that they would not change the rate. Contrastingly, the Bank of Mexico is expected to lower the rate on November 14, adding to appreciation pressure for the peso.

With only one month remaining, I am narrowing the range of my forecast.  Barring a major event, I assume that the MXN will continue to trade in the 19.00 - 20.00 range, with a slight bias towards the lower end where it is currently trading (19.0947 on 30 Oct).
Flattening the curve on consideration that USD may be volatile due to impeachment fallout.
Possible Brexit deal and softening of trade wars shift money flows to riskier markets - emerging economies, Mexico among them. Still, any piece of bad news can reverse the trend.
I don't know why the peso has strengthened over the past two weeks.  But with only 6 weeks left it calls for a small adjustment.  The chance of 18.5 to 19.5 has increased slightly.
Rush for riskier assets due to some lull in trade wars. Will it continue till the end of November? Who knows?

Updating with latest data & reducing SD to 0.2500 (raw data has been calling for a value of closer to 0.1600 but not comfortable with that precision) Forecasted Value: Mex$19.7849 (+/- 0.2500)
Adjustment: [ -, -1, +2, +19, -20 ]
Currently the USD to peso is 19.31.

At Mex$19.8 today it's anticipated that we will see similar Q4 price action in US stocks and therefore USDMXN to last year driven by the USD side. The interesting difference is that the FED was in a hiking cycle last year and now we're in a cutting cycle - this lowers the ceiling on how much the USD can appreciate vs MXN. I'm confident that in the October meeting the FOMC will likely indicate a "risks to the downside" cut in December but this is mostly priced in already. I think US data and CB speak will show an increase in negatives compared to the Mexican economy and Banxico. All of this sounds USD negative but in my view a stock market "correction" in November or negative MXN or global news will be more impactful and we'll see a similar pattern to 2018 Q4 trading with a lower ceiling. My best guess is for MXN to depreciate to Mex$20.2 on Nov 29th.
More of the same old thing.

Supposedly known information - known unknowns: expectations for Fed's and Bank of Mexico to lower/leave the same rates, inflation expectations, (im)probable impeachment - is already priced in. Unknown unknowns more probably will push to peso depreciation - like in all cases of flight to safety.  But of course, nobody knows the future...
Downward pressure on peso. Still close to the 19.5.

Thinking about this abit...  I'm hedging further upwards based on the GM strike. 
A great deal of currency transactions occur as Mexico makes inventory and does JIT delivery.  Parts may cross the border 50 times, per car. Of course, it affects the US economy as well, but IMO the effect on the dollar is far smaller than the effect on the peso. Should the GM UAW strike end soon, I might adjust a few percent depending on where the exchange rate is.

Updating, deviating more strongly from historic base rate in favor of status quo, as the closing date for the question is quite close now.
Crowd: 2,3,42,47,6
Mexico expects two rate cuts, the feds one.

On Aug 27, the Peso hit an 8 month low against the dollar, closed at 20.06
Global growth will likely continue to slow and this will particularly effect the emerging markets/economies of the world, including Mexico. Therefore, the peso will probably remain low against the dollar and possibly continue to lose strength.

During the Trump era, USD/MXN has troughed at 20.1, 20.6 and 20.8, and never strengthened to more that 18.00.
Looks like a broad trading range bound by 20.8 and 18.0 over 2 years with, to me, more weakness suggested than strengthening.
The markets calmed down, which is good for the peso. The question is - for how long and will it be more commotion/flight to safety before November 29? I expect - probably, yes.
The markets calmed down, which works for the Mexican peso. The question is for how long and will it be more commotion before November 29?

Expecting USMCA approval this year rather than next to avoid positive headlines next year. MXN now cheap on all measures, relatively hawkish bancixo, so downside skew to USDMXN. Expect improving sentiment on trade also.
Currently, USD to peso is 20.19 trending up the last few weeks.

Has performed well vs dollar - especially compared to many major currencies - easing of trade tensions and new agreement and US focused on attacking China  Technically has been trending well since Trump took over in 2016 - consolidating pattern during last 18 months - analysis of chart shows that in last 18months it has been trending to lower highs in consolidating pattern $22 / $20.7 / $ 20.42 - whilst also making higher lows - has recently broken above this 'congestion' - if it holds weighting will be reviewed and probably increased towards range of $19.5 - $20.5  Spread currently takes into consideration 'twitter tantrum risk' affecting FED policy

Back in Jan-May 2017 I had the opportunity to study abroad in Mexico. At that time the market value was $1 USD to $19 Pesos. After mark ups and exchange fees it came out to $17.50 Pesos on average. Since then Mexico's formal sector has increased while its informal sector has decreased. There are concerns with Trump's trade war that could indirectly affect the value of the currency via changing how currency circulates in and out of those countries combined with the new renegotiated NAFTA being renamed as the Candad, Mexico US Agreement. Odds of dipping below $17.5 or going above $20.5 are very small. However given past experience and observations combined with recent market trends, its most like going to fall somewhere between $17.5-$19.5 with a 1 in 4 chance of creeping over $19.5. 7 out of 10 simulations would keep it in the $17.5-$19.5 range.
Flight to safety of the greenback, unstoppable even by talks of recession and the most probable Fed rate cut in September... Hmm...

Adjusting upward due to global flight to the dollar. 
Note to self - think about how long will this trend continue.  Look at peso seasonality.

1 United States Dollar equals
19.85 Mexican Peso currently.

Peso became less attractive yesterday as Bank of Mexico cut its interest rate (unexpectedly) by 25 bp. The rate is still hefty 8%, but in the time of troubles dollar looks better bet. Still, IMHO there are prevailing fundamentals - record trade surplus, government aiming for budget surplus (though with Urzua gone, this may change). On the other hand, uncertainty with tariffs from the Trump administration (they were not implemented on condition of Mexican government trying to curb immigration into the US), trade wars etc. will work against the peso.

As before, fundamentals in current state are for peso to appreciate; sentiment - uncertainty about the future, with trade wars, tariffs  - works in the opposite direction...

My view.
Fundamentals are for peso to bounce back, but the sentiment is the opposite: China-US trade woes lead for run to safety of the dollar. Plus unpredictability of Trump administration about migrants and Mexico's role in it.
It may take time to sort it out.

Let's look at fundamentals. So the Fed decreased their base rate by 25 bp and may do it again by the end of 2019.
The Bank of Mexico is expected to hold the base rate on August 15 at impressive 8.25%, Mexico has a recent record trade surplus, NAFTA replacement, USMCA, moved from "no way" to "maybe" in Congress. So the peso is supposed to APPRECIATE, but is depreciating against the dollar. What's going on?
I think it may be because of several things. One is resignation of one of the "cooler heads" in AMLO's government, Urzua, Mexico's finance minister in July, with sharp critique of the AMLO's policies. Secondly, Trump delayed applying tariffs on Mexican goods in June in anticipation of Mexico preventing migrants travelling to the US. My guess is the traders' expectations that Trump's administration will review Mexico following its promises and may still establish tariffs. 
There is of course also a background of a continuing trade spat between the US and China and looming world economy crisis because of that. When something like this is happening, investors run for safety of the dollar - during the financial crisis in 2008, dollar paradoxically appreciated.
So it looks that while fundamentals push for peso appreciation, the sentiment takes over and forces depreciation. And that may continue (or even become worse) for a while...
Just my thoughts, I do not have a crystal ball...
Diminished expectations of further rate cutting from today’s Fed meeting is bullish for the dollar.

I had priced in a us rate cut in November. 
However, considering that expectations of a rate cut have only strengthened the US dollar; and considering that the aggregate of QE around the world is greater effect than US end of normalization the dollar is probably going to continue to appreciate.  Will reconsider if the rate cut changes things in the next few days.

Peso to dollar has been mostly in the 18.5 - 19.5 range for the last year with it spending short periods of time higher than that slightly above 20. Long term trend seems to be in favor of the peso continuing to weaken vs the dollar. In the short term the fed could surprise with a larger than expected rate cut , possibly weakening the dollar relative to the peso.

Update accounting for two improvements in my thinking: 1) Accounting for the latest rate after the peso strengthened following the diffusing of the tension between the US and Mexico: https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/USDMXN:CUR 2) I now use historical data going all the way back to 2009 to estimate the base rate of daily price movement. Previously I had used the last two years as I thought it'd be more representative of recent volatility. However, it seem that following the readjustment after the NAFTA/USMCA negotiation, the peso has been stable (latest tariff volatility notwithstanding) and the volatility more likely to resemble its long term history. The long-term ten-year standard deviation of the daily movements is lower than the one I used previously. Therefore, the distribution of my results has narrowed.
Pres. Trump says the US has reached a deal with Mexico and has suspended tariffs that were to kick in on June 10. The peso is now trading at 19.62

The long-term trend is a weakening of the peso versus the dollar.  That's been true for at least 30-40 years.  That's the economics.  Recent peso weakness is due to politics, and so could reverse any time.  I'm betting that Trump's reelection plan will be to continue to beat up on Mexico.  It plays to his base, which is his favorite strategy.  There are nearly six months left for this challenge, so it's premature to put all my eggs into one basket.  But I am heavily betting that the peso will not strengthen significantly.

Recent weakening of the Peso is keeping my forecast higher than expected. Current forecast is Mex$20.3800 (+/- Mex$0.8500) Adjustment: [ ↔, 1↓, 8↓, 5↑, 4↑ ] Google Sheet: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XIzDkLPzEoOgxqHnZtVE_U7swtQnTDorxSpzMYaiTC4/edit?usp=sharinghttps://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XIzDkLPzEoOgxqHnZtVE_U7swtQnTDorxSpzMYaiTC4/edit?usp=sharing

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-06-05/fitch-downgrades-mexico-while-moody-s-shifts-outlook-to-negative

The Mexican peso defied expectations on Tuesday to become the best performing major currency. Markets confident in team Mexico sent to Washington to negotiate. Rate at $19.59 pesos  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-06-04/not-even-trump-can-dent-mexico-s-best-major-currency-status?utm_campaign=socialflow-organic&utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social&cmpid=socialflow-twitter-business&utm_content=business
with Trump in the white house anything could happen.

5% tariffs kick in June 10, will increase to 10% in July, 15% in August, 20% in Sept, 25% in Oct or so has said the Trump admin. The Mexican gov hinted at retaliating but the AMLO gov is more likely to try to negotiate. 
The Mexican Stock Exchange fell 1.38% Friday, Mexican crude prices dropped 3% to US $56.57 per barrel, the peso lost more than 3% against the dollar before strengthening slightly to trade at just under 20.

Might've gotten myself in trouble w/ being overly precise in my previous forecasts. With recent upticks in value my forecast now points towards a value of ~ Mex$20.38 (Previously Mex$19.36). Recent US tariffs and worsening internal economic performance will destabilize the peso.  It might recover later on if the US/China trade war continues, making Mexico a more attractive source even with the tariffs.
The distribution has shifted up due to Trump’s tariff threat on Mexico.

0.454: Bin 3 - 18.5+ to <19.5

Shifting based on the current value of the USD-MXN (19.0788).

In the past year the value of the US dollar against the Mexican peso has only dipped below MEX$ 17.5 once, in the beginning of last August. While over the past year the value has spent a lot of time above MEX$ 19.5, in 2019 it has only been above MEX$ 19.5 once. Baring any major political or economic shake up, it is very unlikely that value gains above MEX$ 19.5 and unlikely that the value dips below MEX$ 18.5. https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/USDMXN:CUR

Update of algorithmic forecast generated with 'forecast' function from R package of same name applied to monthly (last close) data downloaded from FRED. Algo picked an exponential smoothing model with additive trend and offered a point prediction for the end of November 2019 of 19.32. (Note that historical series from FRED differs slightly from Bloomberg's.)

Adjusted for a bit of a butchered stacked rolling average (pulled data from the past 25 years but that seemed... excessive). Ran for the data since Jan 1st, 2016 & used a 45 day rolling weighted average of the 30 day unweighted average. Weighting was done against the deviation between the 30 day prior value against that given date's value. (Note: This is overly convoluted and could easily be just blind statistics with no meaning, but I enjoyed it. Please dig into this, data will be linked below). Anyways, results from that cluster-F give a predicted value of MEX$19.2500 & a SD of 0.333, and thus the below distribution. Less than MEX$17.500 → 0%
MEX$17.500-18.500 → 1.15%
MEX$18.5000-19.500 → 76.4%
MEX$19.500-20.500 → 22.4%
Above MEX$20.500 → < 1% Adjusting towards this with a deviation from previous forecast of → (↔, ↔, 32↑, 10↓, 22↓). Will certainly update this chart over time & update my forecast towards whatever the resultant value & distribution is. Dataset: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XIzDkLPzEoOgxqHnZtVE_U7swtQnTDorxSpzMYaiTC4/edit?usp=sharing
Inducing a slight downward shift (3↓, 7↓, 10↑, ↔, ↔) due to recent stagnation.
Mexico is doing better than people think.
Based on the occurrences of each Tier since 2016
I looked at the Dollar Peso for the last five years. I might still be too bullish on the extremes.
USDMXN making new 6-month lows, as inversely correlated Mexican equities (EWW) break out to the upside. Next major pivot: USDMXN ~18.75 (bearish below).

I was too pessimistic about the peso, weighing a very high chance of a weakening to above 20.5.  I've increased the chances of stability, i.e., 18.5 to 19.5, but still guessing that the most likely event is 19.5 to 20.5 (53%).
New Mexican government's actions will strengthen Peso.

There has not been a sustained appreciation of the Mexican Peso to the Dollar to any extent close to the first to buckets even in the best of times of economic growth in 30 years.  The peso will trend to devalue as MExican debt grows and is downgraded.  The Mexican Government will try to stabilize prices in a range between 19 and 20 pesos at least for the first year AMLO is in power.

History suggests that long-term the peso always goes down.  The only question is how fast.  There is a lot of noise in the signal, and the eight months before this question closes could see some surprises.
Update of forecast generated by applying the 'forecast' function in the R package of the same name to monthly time series (last close of the month).

Given the following base assumptions to go off...
1) Current effective trading rate (through a simple rolling average) is $19.44
2) Given no external influence this value will trend (with some regression) along the same rate of increase (Need to analyze what some plausible external influences could be)
3) The average quarterly rise in this value is $0.28/quarter (roughly the average from the past 2 years) (This can certainly be poked at more to give a more precise assumption) Evaluating the above gives a value of Mex$20.27 with a SD of 2 quarters of assumed growth rate and roughly the given distribution (with allowance for probability of drop, though TBH I'm not versed in how this portion of the analysis should be done, so I simply distributed rounding errors towards the lower end)

forward right now is already near 20.50 and if anything im slightly dollar bullish only because there has been so much dollar borrowing out there that means if any financial stress you see a bid to the dollar and even if the economy remains strong you still should not see massive bid to the mex given growth there.

Cleaned up the Bank of Mexico numbers from January 1, 2016 to present for a 5 day trading day. Then, ran each day against the same time interval, then binned the differentials based on today's price against the question breaks. Result is now: 0.094: Bin 1 - <17.5
0.109: Bin 2 - 17.5 to <=18.5
0.258: Bin 3 - 18.5+ to <19.5
0.254: Bin 4 - 19.5 to <=20.5
0.285: Bin 5 - 20.5+

My primary assumption is that MXN will continue to trade within 18.00 - 20.50 range seen over the last few years  (thank you @sreichau for historical chart [1] and @ddorsey for additional comments [2]). Worldfirst also put out a survey of currency forecasts, with bulk of forecasts in 18-21 range (outlier at 22, none below 18) [3]. The long-term historical trend towards the MXN weakening over time skews my risks somewhat towards further weakening.   [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/825720
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/826102

Update based on latest price and Random Walk Monte Carlo simulations.  @nigster, I am curious why you are not participating here. It seems like there is a big divergence between the crowd and results from a data-based approach (unless I got something wrong in my calculations). Could be that this question offers an opportunity to beat the crowd by a lot. Unlike the stock indexes questions that seem to have attracted only data-based folks.
People are not accounting for volatility. I don't have a forecast but stuff happens.

Going to have to keep updating this question given the time frame and volatility of the currency pair. Looking at the last six months the currency hasn't fallen below 18.5 and has only been above 20.5 briefly. I really wish I cared more about currency movements to do some real research but here we are with a very simple distribution.

Outside view: I am using 10 years of daily trading data to build a Random Walk with 10,000 Monte Carlo simulations as described here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/816322 Current price: 19.3278
Days remaining: estimated 214 ( = 291 total days * (6/7) since it trades 6 days a week) Result: 23, 16, 17, 15, 29. Comment: The spread is much larger than I expected. Notably, the standard deviation of the daily % change is 0.7% (seems like a lot - in contrast the British pound has been much stabler in the last two years with a SD of 0.4%). Also of note is the fact that the timeframe for this question is rather long, which suggests a wide range of possibilities. Inside view: The data encompasses a lot of volatility around 2015-2016 associated with Trump's trade policy and the renegotiation of NAFTA. Was that a one-off type of readjustment event? Are we in a new equilibrium? Yet, even if I only use the last two years of data, the spread is larger (SD of 0.8 in that time period). For now, I trust the outside view from the model results.

Thanks @sreichau for the historical chart. Visual analysis yields a few key findings: - Last major high Jan'17 at ~21.5.
- Consolidation/correction periods (like the one we're in) run ~3.5-4 years.
- Consolidations "average" -12% from established high to low (~24% for extremes).
- Consolidations feature a series of lower highs. Based on these our realistic range is ~18-20.5, ruling out the top and bottom buckets, and half of 17.5-18.5. Accordingly, I'll go with a straddle of remaining buckets, w/ downside bias per bearish USD view.

Looking at historical data from: https://www.macrotrends.net/2559/us-dollar-mexican-peso-exchange-rate-historical-chart
There seems to be a sort of equilibrium from the start of 2016. Probabilities for this initial forecast is the number of days with a closing value in the respective bracket divided by the total number of days since 2016/01/01. To do: investigate if there are data points that indicate that the future exchange rate might deviate from the apparent equilibrium, and if yes, which direction.
